Two types of 5 %wt Ru/AC catalysts were prepared using carbon carriers treated with 5 mol L−1 HNO3 and 5 mol L−1 HCl by the impregnation method, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physical adsorption, XRD, XPS, SEM, TEM and ICP-AES. The catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts for the decomposition of hydroxylamine nitrate (HAN) and hydrazine nitrate (HN) was evaluated. The results demonstrated that both catalysts exhibited complete decomposition of HAN and HN under moderate reaction conditions (70–90 ℃), displaying similar activities. And the catalysts treated with hydrochloric acid exhibited better stability and can be reused 128 cycles. Furthermore, the experimental results on various parameters indicate that an increase in temperature and nitric acid concentration leads to a reduction in reaction time. The catalytic performance of Ru/AC catalyst remains unchanged after 20 cycles under radioactive conditions, exhibiting exceptional radiation resistance. Graphical Abstract Keywords Acid treatment Activated carbon Ru catalysts Catalytic decomposition Hydroxylamine nitrate Hydrazine nitrate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the Purex process, Pu (IV) is selectively reduced to Pu (III) by leveraging the difference in the distribution ratio of tributyl phosphate (TBP), thereby facilitating the extraction of Pu into the aqueous phase for achieving the separation of uranium and plutonium. Commonly employed reducing agents include hydroxylamine nitrate (HAN), with hydrazine nitrate (HN) acting as a stabilizer [1–3]. During the reduction process, a substantial volume of the secondary radioactive waste fluid is generated, which contains HNO3 (0.8–1.8 mol L−1), HAN (0.3 mol L−1), and HN (0.1 mol L−1) [4]. To minimize secondary radioactive waste and recover nitric acid, a significant quantity of raffinates containing HNO3 and reducing agents should be processed via continuous evaporation and denitration [5]. However, the presence of HAN and HN is counterproductive to the waste treatment process, as it frequently exacerbates the complexity of treatment. Furthermore, the HAN has the potential to produce a substantial amount of nitrite through an autocatalytic reaction within a brief period, posing a hazard due to the potential for a chemical explosion during high-temperature treatment [6]. Hence, the decomposition of HAN and HN is crucial for achieving the ultimate safe disposal of radioactive waste. Currently, the utilization of supported noble metal catalysts for the removal of HAN and HN represents a cutting-edge, highly efficient, and environmentally sustainable approach. The catalytic decomposition of high concentrations or pure HAN and hydrazine as monopropellants has been comprehensively documented in the paper [7–12]. The majority of catalysts' active components consist of noble metals, including Ir and Pt, alongside SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 as carriers. The heterogeneous catalytic decomposition of HAN in a HNO3 system has not been reported. Anan'ev reported on the catalytic decomposition mechanism and kinetics of hydrazine in HNO3, leveraging Ru/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts. These studies demonstrated that heterogeneous catalysis represents a promising approach for the decomposition of HN [13,14]. However, the studies focus solely on the decomposition of HAN or hydrazine individually, rendering them inapplicable to the mentioned spent fuel reprocessing system where simultaneous decomposition of both HAN and HN in the nitric acid system is imperative. The utilization of activated carbon as a carrier for supported catalysts is highly advantageous due to its low cost, exceptional adsorption capacity, and superior mechanical strength. Acid treatment represents a commonly employed method for the purification of activated carbon, effectively eliminating surface impurities (such as ash) while simultaneously introducing beneficial functional groups (such as carboxyl, phenol, alcohol, etc.) that enhance catalyst performance. Mao et al. investigated the effects of acid treatment on activated carbon used as a support for Rb and K catalysts in C2F5I synthesis, finding that acid treatment effectively enhanced metal ion dispersion on the catalysts [15]. The order of catalyst dispersion was as follows: Rb-K/AC-HNO3 > Rb-K/AC-HF > Rb-K/AC-HCl > Rb-K/AC, with a similar trend observed regarding the amount of the acid surface oxygen groups on AC. Xue et al. investigated the effects of wet oxidation in HNO3, H2O2, and H2SO4 aqueous solutions on the surface properties of activated carbon, as well as the role of activated carbon surface properties in adsorption and reduction of NO on CuO catalysts [16]. The findings demonstrated that wet oxidation treatment effectively enhances the abundance of oxygen functional groups on the carbon surface, thereby facilitating improved dispersion of CuO and enhancing its adsorption capacity for NO. Kristianto et al. investigated the effects of HNO3 surface modification on activated carbon for Fe catalysts used in the synthesis of CNSs [17]. It was observed that HNO3 treatment resulted in an increased loading of Fe on the catalyst. And it was suggested that this enhancement may be attributed to an augmentation in oxygen-containing functional groups. This modification rendered the carbon surface more hydrophilic, thereby facilitating a stronger interaction between the metal catalyst and support. The utilization of Ru catalysts has been extensively investigated and widely implemented across diverse disciplines [18–21]. However, the investigation and application of Ru/AC catalyst for the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN in the nitrate acid system have not yet been extensively reported. To investigate the effect of acid treatment on the modification of activated carbon of the Ru/AC catalyst and remove acid soluble impurities present in the carrier, two types of 5 %wt Ru/AC catalysts were prepared using carbon carriers treated with 5 mol L−1 HNO3 and 5 mol L−1 HCl by the impregnation method, respectively, in this study. The simultaneous catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN in a HNO3 system was investigated. The influence of several factors, such as reaction temperature, the concentrations of HNO3, HAN, and HN and radioactivity, on catalyst activity was also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material and regents RuCl3·xH2O (AR, 37.5–41 wt% Ru) purchased from Titan Scientific Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). HNO3 (AR, 69 wt%) and hydrazine hydrate (AR, 85 wt%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Regent Co., Ltd. HN was synthesized through the neutralization reaction of hydrazine hydrate and HNO3. HAN (AR, 10 wt%) was purchased from Beijing Aerospace Kane New Materials Co., Ltd. AC was purchased from Henan Tonghui Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Tributyl phosphate (TBP, AR) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Kerosene (OK, AR) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of Ru/AC catalyst The activated carbon was subjected to multiple washes with deionized water until the washing solution became clear. It was then dried and stored. The activated carbon was then treated with 5 mol L−1 HNO3 or 5 mol L−1 HCl at a solid-liquid ratio of 1:10 for 10 h at 50℃. Subsequently, it was thoroughly rinsed with deionized water until the pH of the washing solution reached about 7, followed by drying at room temperature. The resulting samples were labeled as NAC and ClAC, respectively. The Ru-supported activated carbon was fabricated using a wet impregnation technique. Typically, 1.35 g of RuCl3·xH2O was dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water, followed by its addition to 10 g of activated carbon. The mixture was then adsorbed at room temperature for 24 h. Afterward, the solvent was completely evaporated at 120 °C. Finally, the impregnated catalyst was subjected to calcination using nitrogen at 450 ℃ for 2 h, followed by hydrogen treatment at 300 ℃ for 3 h, resulting in the preparation of Ru/AC catalyst. Catalysts with NAC and ClAC as the carriers were recorded as Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC, respectively. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The specific surface areas of the prepared materials were determined by N2 physical adsorption at 77 K, following the degassing of the samples using a Micromeritics Model ASAP 2010 instrument. The specific surface area of the sample was measured employing the BET method. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku MiniFlex 600 Cu Kα) was obtained to characterize the crystal structure of Ru. The X-ray tube voltage is set at 40 kV, with a tube current of 30 mA, and the scanning range spans from 2θ=10° to 90°. The morphology of activated carbon and Ru/AC catalysts was visualized by scanning electron microscope (SEM, PHENOM G2) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-F200) after pulverizing them into powders finer than 200 mesh. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI-5702) was employed to investigate the chemical state and elemental composition of the catalysts. The electron binding energy was calibrated using the carbon standard C 1 s binding energy (284.8 eV) with the pass energy set to 50 eV, and the data underwent peak fitting analysis using software. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, ICAT6000) was employed to measure the actual content of Ru in the catalysts. Take an appropriate amount of catalyst sample in a crucible and heat it at 420°C for 3 h, followed by cooling to room temperature using a dryer. Subsequently, grind the sample to achieve particle size below 200 mesh. Employing the aqua regia system, dissolve the sample at 200°C for 30 min utilizing a microwave digestion instrument (MARS6), and subsequently determine the Ru content through ICP-AES analysis. 2.4 HAN and HN concentrations analysis The concentrations of HAN and HN were determined using ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometry. The hydroxylamine exhibits the ability to effectively reduce Fe3+ ions to Fe2+ ions in solution. In a pH range of 2–9, o-phenanthrene undergoes a colour reaction with Fe2+ ions. This reaction demonstrates remarkable selectivity and yields a highly stable orange-red complex, exhibiting maximum absorption at 510 nm. By utilizing this colour reaction, trace amounts of HAN can be accurately quantified through spectrophotometry. Under acidic conditions, hydrazine undergoes a colour reaction with p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde. The absorbance is measured at 457 nm. And the concentration of hydrazine exhibits proportionality to the measured absorbance within a specific range, thereby enabling accurate determination of its concentration. 2.5 Activity evaluation of catalyst 2.5.1 General activity evaluation The catalytic decomposition reaction of HAN and HN in HNO3 was carried out using a batch reaction unit. Typically, at a solid-liquid ratio of 1:20, 1 g of prepared catalyst (dry weight), 20 mL of feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, and 1 mol L−1 HNO3, using 30 V/V% TBP/OK balance) were added to a round-bottom flask equipped with a condensation reflux device, and the water bath was heated to 80℃. The reaction time was recorded. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration and directly reused in the model reaction for the subsequent cycle. The experimental observation reveals a gradual decrease in the rate of bubble formation, followed by a sudden surge in bubble production due to the self-catalysis of hydroxylamine nitrate towards the end of the reaction. At this stage, the measured liquid exhibits concentrations lower than 10−4 mol/L for both hydroxylamine nitrate and hydrazine nitrate, indicating complete decomposition of these compounds. The main products of the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN are N2O, N2, NO, and NH4 +, as shown in Fig. S3 and Fig. S4. 2.5.2 Radioactive activity evaluation To simulate radioactive operating conditions, the radioactive feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, 1 mol L−1 HNO3, 10−5 g/L Pu (239Pu, 238Pu and 240Pu), 10−4 g/L 237Np and 10−3 g/L U (mainly 238U)) was prepared with 30 %TBP/OK balance. The other activity evaluation procedures are the same as the general activity evaluation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst The activated carbons and catalysts were characterized using N2 physical adsorption employing the BET method, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The Ru metal content of the fresh Ru/ClAC and fresh Ru/NAC catalysts was determined to be 4.87%wt and 4.96%wt, respectively, using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The physical structural parameters of the activated carbons and catalysts were determined using N2 physical adsorption at 77 K employing the BET method. The BET specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of activated carbon, acid-treated activated carbon, as well as fresh and used Ru/ClAC for 128 cycles, fresh and reused Ru/NAC for 78 cycles are presented in Table 1. The results indicate that the impact of all treatments on the pore size is minimal. Acid treatment (Table 1, Entry 2 and 3) induces a reduction in the BET specific surface area and pore volume of activated carbon. This phenomenon can be attributed to the obstruction of micropores by HNO3 and HCl ions, as well as the formation of transitional pores during the treatment process[22]. Moreover, HCl demonstrates a more pronounced impact compared to HNO3. The BET specific surface area and pore volume of Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC (Table 1, Entry 4 and 5) are partially restored, in comparison to NAC and ClAC. This restoration can be attributed to the reaction between hydrogen and elements such as S, Cl, N, O during the high-temperature reduction process with hydrogen gas[23], leading to their elimination and subsequent enhancement of the catalysts' BET specific surface area and pore volume. The BET specific surface area and pore volume of both catalysts (Table 1, Entry 6 and 7) decrease after usage, indicating alterations in the activated carbon's pore structure during its utilization process. Furthermore, the Ru/ClAC catalyst exhibits a more pronounced decline, potentially attributed to its extended cyclic utilization duration. The catalyst was characterized by XRD to investigate the loading of Ru on the carrier, and the corresponding results are presented in Fig. 1. Fig. 1(a) displays the XRD patterns of fresh Ru/NAC and fresh Ru/ClAC. In comparison with the standard card of Ru (pdf#06-0663), no characteristic peak associated with Ru species is observed, indicating excellent dispersion and small particle size of Ru on both Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC. The XRD images of used Ru/NAC and used Ru/ClAC, as depicted in Fig. 1(b), did not exhibit any discernible characteristic absorption peak associated with Ru. Only a minor protrusion was observed within the 2θ range of 40° to 45° in the XRD image of used Ru/ClAC, indicating a weak degree of polymerization for the Ru particles. Fig. 2 presents SEM images of fresh and reused Ru/ClAC for 128 cycles, as well as fresh and reused Ru/NAC for 78 cycles. The AC, as depicted in Fig. 2(a), exhibits a smooth surface and a well-defined pore structure. The pore structures of Ru/ClAC (Fig. 2(b)) and Ru/NAC (Fig. 2(c)) remain relatively intact. However, there are some surface and edge damages, potentially resulting from sample fragmentation prior to SEM analysis. After 128 cycles, the surface of the Ru/ClAC catalyst (Fig. 2(d)) exhibits a smooth appearance, with still discernible intact pore structures. However, there is a noticeable augmentation in surface impurities and certain pore structures have suffered from corrosion damage, as well as all the channels are severely blocked. The observed phenomenon suggests that the reduction in specific surface area and pore volume following the utilization of Ru/ClAC catalyst can be attributed to pore blockage. After 78 cycles, the Ru/NAC catalyst (Fig. 2(e)) exhibited less pronounced pore blockage compared to the utilized Ru/ClAC catalyst. However, its surface and pore structure suffered from significant corrosion and damage, indicating that the oxidizing effect of HNO3 can render the activated carbons' pore structure more vulnerable. The loading status of Ru particles on the catalyst surface was further confirmed through TEM analysis of fresh and reused Ru/ClAC after 128 cycles, as well as fresh and reused Ru/NAC after 78 cycles, as shown in Fig. 3. The surfaces of fresh Ru/ClAC (Fig. 3(a)) and Ru/NAC (Fig. 3(b)) exhibited uniformly dispersed Ru particles with excellent loading. However, a significant decrease in the number of Ru particles was observed on the surface of used Ru/ClAC (Fig. 3(c)), with remaining particles showing aggregation phenomenon. In contrast, the TEM image of used Ru/NAC (Fig. 3(d)) revealed that uniformly dispersed Ru particles could still be observed on the surface. XPS was employed to ascertain the oxidation state of Ru in catalysts and qualitatively analyze the Ru content. The corresponding results are presented in Fig. 4. Based on the full-spectrum scanning spectrum of Ru/ClAC (Fig. 4(a)), the catalyst primarily comprises C, O, Si, Cl and Ru elements. In Ru XPS analysis, the Ru 3d orbitals with strong characteristic absorption peaks are usually selected. However, as shown in Fig. 4(b), due to the extremely strong characteristic absorption peak of the C 1 s orbital and its overlap with the characteristic absorption peak of the Ru 3d1/2 orbital, it becomes difficult to effectively analyze the XPS spectrum of the Ru 3d orbitals. Therefore, the Ru 3p orbitals were selected for XPS analysis, as depicted in Fig. 4(c) and (d). However, owing to the low Ru content and the weak intensity of characteristic absorption peaks in the Ru 3p orbitals, a higher level of noise is observed in the resultant signals. It is evident that the fresh and used catalysts exhibit two distinct Ru species, characterized by binding energies at 462.2 eV and 463.3 eV, corresponding to Ru(0) and RuO2, respectively [24]. The dominant surface Ru species in fresh catalysts is Ru(0), as evidenced by the data presented in Table 2. The Ru(0) species content on the surface of fresh Ru/ClAC is higher compared to that on fresh Ru/NAC, potentially attributed to the oxidative properties of HNO3, which can introduce a greater number of oxygen-containing functional groups into NAC. The content of surface Ru(0) species in fresh Ru/NAC is 60 %. However, it gradually decreases to 55 % after 78 cycles. This observation suggests that during usage, the surface Ru(0) species undergo progressive oxidation and transformation into RuO2. From Fig. 4(c) and (d), it is evident that the characteristic absorption peak of Ru 3p in the catalyst significantly diminishes upon usage, particularly for Ru/ClAC where the mentioned peak has completely vanished. This indicates a substantial loss of Ru from the catalyst during operation. The Ru metal content of the used Ru/ClAC and used Ru/NAC catalysts was determined to be 1.13%wt and 2.75%wt, respectively, using ICP-AES, which is consistent with the above results. To further investigate the Ru loss mechanism, the concentration of Ru in the solution after the conclusion of the reaction was determined using ICP-AES, and the results are presented in Fig. 5. The findings revealed a similar exponential decrease in Ru loss for both catalysts, which contribute to this phenomenon. Firstly, due to gas generation and agitation, Ru particles with weak adsorption forces on activated carbon undergo rapid desorption. Secondly, as activated carbon experiences corrosion damage and mass loss, the Ru particles adsorbed on it are gradually lost over time. During the initial stages of cycling, many weakly adsorbed Ru particles lead to dominant rapid losses. However, during the middle and late stages of cycling, the concentration of Ru in solution tends towards stability with gradual losses occurring at a slower rate. Consequently, significant Ru loss from catalysts is also an important factor contributing to their deactivation. 3.2 Catalyst activity and stability evaluation The activity of the prepared catalyst for the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN was evaluated in feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, and 1 mol L−1 HNO3) at 80 ℃. As shown in Table 3, the decomposition reaction proceeds at a significantly slower rate in the absence of a catalyst (Table 3, Entry 1) or when AC alone is present (Table 3, Entry 2). Both HAN and HN exhibit low decomposition rates after reacting for 60 min. The decomposition rate refers to the extent of HAN and HN decomposition. However, when Ru/AC (Table 3, Entry 3), Ru/NAC (Table 3, Entry 4) and Ru/ClAC (Table 3, Entry 5) were employed as catalysts, the decomposition rates of HAN and HN reached 99.99 %. This demonstrates that Ru exhibits exceptional performance for the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN. The reaction time of Ru/AC is significantly prolonged compared to that of Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC, indicating that acid treatment can enhance the catalyst's activity. Furthermore, the similarity in activities between both treatments suggests that while HNO3 treatment can enhance the adsorption capacity of activated carbon for metal ions by introducing more oxygen-containing functional groups, as shown in Fig. S5, it does not significantly impact catalyst activity at the same Ru content. The catalytic recyclability of 1 g Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC catalysts was evaluated in feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, and 1 mol L−1 HNO3) at 80 ℃. In the cycling experiment, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture through simple filtration and directly reused in subsequent rounds of the model reaction without requiring additional purification steps. The repetitive experiments of Ru/ClAC catalyst demonstrated the reproducibility of catalytic decomposition results, as shown in Fig. S6. If the reaction time exceeds 60 min, it can be inferred that the catalyst has undergone deactivation, thereby precluding any further experimental investigations. As depicted in Fig. 6, Ru/NAC could be reused up to 78 times while Ru/ClAC exhibited reusability for up to 128 cycles, achieving complete decomposition rates of HAN and HN. Throughout the cycling process, Ru/NAC exhibits instability in catalytic performance due to its significant variation range in reaction time. Moreover, the activities of both Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC progressively decline as the number of cycles increases. Reveal the factors contributing to catalyst deactivation through an analysis of characterization results obtained for the catalyst. The N2 physical adsorption results (Table 1) demonstrate a reduction in the BET specific surface area and pore volume of used Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC, indicating alterations in the catalyst's pore structure post-use, which constitutes one of the primary causes for catalyst deactivation. The SEM image (Fig. 2) demonstrates that pore blockage and corrosion have resulted in a reduction in both BET specific surface area and pore volume. On one hand, this will lead to a reduction in the available reaction surface area. On the other hand, it will result in substantial Ru loss and agglomeration of Ru particles during utilization, as evidenced by TEM image (Fig. 3) and XPS image (Fig. 4), which also constitutes one of the pivotal factors contributing to catalyst deactivation. During usage, the detachment of Ru loaded on activated carbon due to mechanical action caused by gas generation and agitation as another significant factor contributing to Ru loss in the process. In addition, the results presented in Table 2 further illustrate the gradual oxidation of the main active species Ru(0) to RuO2, which significantly contributes to catalyst deactivation. The Ru/NAC achieved a limited number of 78 cycles of reuse, as depicted in Fig. 6, whereas the Ru/ClAC exhibited an extended durability with 128 cycles. The presence of HNO3 exhibit potent oxidizing properties, which can render the pore structure of activated carbon more vulnerable and prone to corrosion and damage during usage. This observation is supported by the SEM image (Fig. 2). Conversely, despite experiencing a more pronounced reduction in BET specific surface area and pore volume upon utilization, Ru/ClAC does not exhibit severe corrosion of its pore structure. This observation underscores the pivotal role played by the porous architecture of activated carbon in catalyst activity. The higher abundance of fresh Ru(0) species on the Ru/ClAC surface additionally contributes to an extended buffering time for its oxidation. 3.3 Influencing factors of catalyst performance The concentrations of HNO3, HAN, and HN in the waste liquid may exhibit fluctuations during the actual treatment process. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate the influence of various reaction conditions on catalyst activity. The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance for the decomposition of HAN and HN was investigated in model feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, and 1 mol L−1 HNO3), as presented in Table 4. The activity of both catalysts exhibited a gradual increase with rising temperature. At lower temperatures (60 ℃), the catalytic activity of Ru/ClAC surpasses that of Ru/NAC. However, at moderate temperatures (70–90 ℃), their activities exhibit similarity. As all subsequent experiments were conducted under moderate temperature conditions, the ensuing discussion will solely focus on the performance of Ru/ClAC. Regarding Ru/ClAC, Fig. 7 illustrates the relationship between reaction time and temperature. The reaction time exhibits an exponential decrease as the temperature increases, indicating an accelerated decomposition rate with higher temperatures. However, higher reaction temperature will increase the gas production of catalytic decomposition reactions per unit time leading to carrier breakage. Based on these considerations, it is recommended to select a reaction temperature about 80 ℃. To investigate the impact of HNO3 concentration on catalyst activity, a series of experiments were conducted at 80℃ using 0.3 mol L−1 HAN and 0.1 mol L−1 HN as reactants, and the results are presented in Fig. 8. As the HNO3 concentration increased from 1 mol L−1 to 3 mol L−1, the reaction time decreased from 17 min to 5 min. At lower concentrations (ranging from 1.0 mol L−1 to 2.5 mol L−1), there was a linear relationship between reaction time and HNO3 concentration observed. The probable reason behind this phenomenon is that the concentration of nitrite in the solution exhibits a linear increase corresponding to the concentration of HNO3. However, at higher concentrations (above 2.5 mol L−1), the reaction time tended to stabilize due to the limited number of active sites. The results are consistent with the paper [13]. Several papers [13,14,25] have investigated the catalytic decomposition mechanism and kinetics of HAN and HN, indicating that the decomposition process occurs as depicted in reactions (1) to (4). (1) 2HNO3 + Ru → 2 HNO2 + RuO2 (2) NH3OH + + 2 HNO3 → 3 HNO 2 + H 2 O + H + (3) NH 3 OH + + HNO 2 → N2O + 2 H 2 O + H + (4) N 2 H5 + + HNO 2 → HN 3 + 2 H 2 O + H + As illustrated in reaction (1), the catalytic decomposition of HNO3 into HNO2 and its derivatives is a pivotal step in the reaction, followed by subsequent reactions between HNO2 and HAN or HN. Hence, the concentration of HNO2 plays a crucial role in influencing the reaction rate. The interaction between hydroxylamine and HNO2 is particularly intriguing due to its ability to either generate more HNO2 through autocatalysis (reaction (2)) or consume existing HNO2 (reaction (3)). Elevated temperature and increased concentration of HNO3 both promote reaction (2), resulting in higher concentrations of HNO2 which subsequently enhance the reaction rate and reduce overall reaction time, as shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2 [26]. However, considering limitations imposed by active sites on catalysts, there exists an upper limit for achieving maximum attainable reaction rate when temperature and concentration of HNO3 are high. The impact of HAN and HN concentrations on their decomposition rates was investigated through a series of experiments conducted in a 1 mol L−1 HNO3 at 80℃. The results are presented in Fig. 9. From reaction (2) to reaction (4), upon completion of the decomposition of hydrazine in solution, the residual hydroxylamine undergoes autocatalytic reaction 2 and rapidly decomposes within a significantly short duration. Hence, it is imperative to focus on assessing the impact of variations in HAN and HN concentrations on the rate of HN decomposition. The increase in the concentration of HAN from 0.1 mol L−1 to 0.5 mol L−1 did not result in a significant change in reaction time, with only a slight reduction observed, as illustrated in Fig. 9(a). The augmentation of HAN concentration escalated the rate of reactions (2) and (3). However, these two reactions display competitive behavior, leading to a modest increase in the concentration of HNO2 and correspondingly, a slight acceleration in the decomposition rate of HN. As depicted in Fig. 9(b), the increase in the concentration of HN from 0.05 mol L−1 to 0.25 mol L−1 corresponded to an augmentation in the reaction time from 10 min to 38 min. Since HNO2 is the catalyst for the reaction (2), the acceleration of the rate of reaction (4) with the increment in the concentration of HN led to a competitive reduction in the rate of reaction (2), further causing a decline in the concentration of HNO2 in the solution. This, in turn, imposed a constraint on the decomposition rate of HN. In summary, both catalysts exhibit complete decomposition of HAN and HN in the liquid feed comprising HNO3 (0.5–2.5 mol L−1), HAN (0.1–0.5 mol L−1), and HN (0.05–0.25 mol L−1) at moderate reaction temperatures ranging from 60 to 90 ℃. 3.4 The effect of radioactivity on catalyst performance To investigate the effect of radioactivity on catalyst performance, the activity of the Ru/ClAC for the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN was evaluated in radioactive feed liquid (0.3 mol L−1 HAN, 0.1 mol L−1 HN, 1 mol L−1 HNO3, 10−5 g/L Pu, 10−4 g/L Np and 10−3 g/L U) at 80 ℃. As shown in Fig. 10, Ru/ClAC can achieve complete decomposition of HAN and HN within a short time of 23 min under radioactive conditions. The catalytic performance remains unchanged after 20 cycles, exhibiting a similar level to that observed in general feed liquid. The results demonstrated that the effect of radioactivity on the catalytic activity of Ru/ClAC was negligible, and Ru/ClAC exhibited exceptional radiation resistance. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the Ru/AC catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance in the catalytic decomposition of HAN and HN in nitric acid. Treatment with 5 mol L−1 HNO3 and 5 mol L−1 HCl leads to a reduction in the BET specific surface area and pore volume of activated carbon, primarily due to micropore blockage and formation of transitional pores. The catalysts Ru/NAC and Ru/ClAC prepared from both treatments exhibit similar performance in catalytic decomposition towards HAN and HN nitrate in HNO3 at moderate temperatures (70–90 ℃). However, while the Ru/NAC catalyst withstands only 78 cycles, the Ru/ClAC catalyst endures up to 128 cycles. This can be attributed to the increased fragility of activated carbon's pore walls caused by the strong oxidizing nature of nitric acid, resulting in rapid corrosion and deactivation of the Ru/NAC during usage. The rate of decomposition of HAN and HN increases with increasing reaction temperature, and the optimal temperature is 80 ℃. The decomposition time exhibits a linear decline with the increment of HNO3 concentration at low concentrations, yet it tends to stabilize at higher concentrations. The probable reason is that the generating of HNO2 is restrained by the catalyst's active site when the concentration of HNO3 is elevated, thereby preventing further increase in its concentration. Both catalysts exhibit complete decomposition of HAN and HN in the liquid feed comprising HNO3 (0.5–2.5 mol L−1), HAN (0.1–0.5 mol L−1), and HN (0.05–0.25 mol L−1) at moderate reaction temperatures ranging from 60 to 90 ℃. The catalytic performance of Ru/AC catalyst remains unchanged after 20 cycles under radioactive conditions, exhibiting exceptional radiation resistance. coredata.dc:description: Two types of 5 %wt Ru/AC catalysts were prepared using carbon carriers treated with 5 mol L−1 HNO3 and 5 mol L−1 HCl by the impregnation method, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physical adsorption, XRD, XPS, SEM, TEM and ICP-AES. The catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts for the decomposition of hydroxylamine nitrate (HAN) and hydrazine nitrate (HN) was evaluated. The results demonstrated that both catalysts exhibited complete decomposition of HAN and HN under moderate reaction conditions (70–90 ℃), displaying similar activities. And the catalysts treated with hydrochloric acid exhibited better stability and can be reused 128 cycles. Furthermore, the experimental results on various parameters indicate that an increase in temperature and nitric acid concentration leads to a reduction in reaction time. The catalytic performance of Ru/AC catalyst remains unchanged after 20 cycles under radioactive conditions, exhibiting exceptional radiation resistance.
